intro: Leptodactylon pungens var. hallii, commonly known as the Hall's spurge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It typically grows to a height of 15–30 cm, featuring upright, branching stems covered in fine, sticky hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in clusters, which are followed by distinctive, bead-like seed capsules. Its leaves are alternate, ovate to elliptic in shape, and often have a slightly succulent texture. This species is adapted to survive in harsh environments, exhibiting drought tolerance and a shallow root system.
